description: On March 16, the Edo State Government has called on residents to avoid spreading malicious and unverified information about Covid-19 aimed at causing panic.
Between the 16th and 24th of February 2020, through the Director General of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, the World Health Organization deployed a high-level mission to China.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Nasarawa State,Nigeria, cautioned residents against spreading fake news on coronavirus that could cause panic in the state on March 25 an stated: “The public should rely only on information from government and experts on COVID-19 and not allow themselves to be misled by some unpatriotic elements whose aim is to cause confusion,”.

Osun state, Nigeria, announced April 2 that the governor has signed the Osun Infectious Diseases (Emergency Prevention) Regulations 2020. Under the law transmission or dissemination of false information regarding Covid-19 is an offense and anybody who violates the law will be sentenced to six-month imprisonment or an option of fine upon conviction.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On April 14, Dr Abubakar Ayinla, the Permanent Secretary, state Ministry of Health said that the state government has set up the Risk Communication teams, among others, to manage rumours and fake news circulating as regards COVID-19 in the state.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On April 16, Kogi State Governor, Alhaji Yahaya Bello has denied ever trivialising Covid-19 pandemic as untrue, political and an avenue for corrupt public officials to enrich themselves as claimed in recent social media reports. He is urging the public and good people of Kogi State to disregard the said fake news churned out by agents of mischief whose stock in trade is to mislead the people and cause disaffection in the society.

On May 2, the Edo State governor in Nigeria urged journalists to uphold the ethics of the journalism profession and live up to their responsibilities of providing reliable and credible information to the public amid COVID-19.
Ondo state, Nigeria, on May 8 urges journalists to only publish verified reports.

On May 15, Kwara State Governor, AbdulRahman AbdulRazaq, said the man in a recent video that went viral on social media was not a suspected COVID-19 patient. The governor, who disclosed this during a visit to the state’s isolation centre in Ilorin, however, told journalists that the man was inappropriately evacuated from his home in Ilorin.

On June 2, Edo State Government received Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials from World Health Organization (WHO) to disseminate of actionable &, credible messages and promote Health & communicate risk, especially during outbreaks such as COVID-19.
target_geog_level: An international organization (e.g. World Health Organization)
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 16th, 2020, Nigeria conducted training of health reporters and journalists on factual reporting on COVID-19 in Kano State. The primary goal was to prevent the spread of fake news surrounding COVID-19 and its status in the country. The non-governmental organization "Breakthrough Action-Nigeria" as well as the Federal Ministry of Health conducted the training in order to help reporters and journalists identify scams, fabricated information, and conspiracy theories, among other issues, before proliferating information and sources.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Nigeria, june 26 - a recent collaboration of the Borno State Government with the World Health Organisation to launch a campaign tagged ‘COVID-19 Heroes Campaign’ launched on May 29 in Borno State.The deputy governor noted that the campaign was aimed at demystifying COVID-19 and putting a stop to the stigmatisation of those affected by the pandemic, adding that sufferers of the disease should be celebrated by all rather than stigmatised.

Osun state, Nigeria, has a one-day training program on Covid-19 reporting for selected radio reporters on July 1. The programme is organized by the Ministry of Information and Civic Orientation in collaboration with the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund(UNICEF).

The Anambra State Government of Nigeria announced on July 13, 2020 that they were aware of a group of criminals parading in fake Covid-19 Task Force uniforms. These criminals had been arresting people and extorting huge sums of money from them while posturing as working for the government of Anambra State. The government indicated that the only agencies authorized to enforce the Anambra State Covid-19 Law are the members of OCHA Brigade and ATMA. Additionally, the government warned these fake operators that the Anambra State Police Command has been directed to search for, arrest and prosecute anybody masquerading as a Covid-19 Task Force operator.

The Honourable Minister of Health, Dr. Osagie Ehanire has called for caution amid declining cases of COVID-19 in the country as he said this could be attributed to the fact that we are yet to perfect our act in the containment of the virus. Dr. Ehanire gave this caution during the Presidential Task Force (PTF) on COVID-19 Press Briefing in Abuja on Monday, 30th August, 2020.

In his words, “We are beginning to see a situation where the number of those treated and discharged exceeds the number of positive cases detected. While these figures may seem reassuring, they may be deceptive, and we cannot assume that the curve is flattening, since we are yet to perfect due diligence on our side.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
14 September 2020 | Abuja – Update on the Nigeria International Travel Portal

Our attention has been drawn to a report published by the Daily Independent newspaper on the 14th of September 2020, with the title: “Fraud Rocks NCDC COVID-19 Tests For Air Travellers”

This report is simply incorrect and based on information that is inconsistent with the truth. In addition, no attempt was made to contact the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) on this matter before the newspaper went to press. This article is an unfortunate misrepresentation of efforts by Government Ministries and Agencies, to enable safe travel in the context of a pandemic affecting every country in the world.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Nigeria Goverment is aware that Tweets wishing Trump dies of COVID-19 will be removed  from Twittwe
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020.

Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020. On 28th of March Governor Atiku Bagudu of Kebbi state also ordered that all schools including Islamiyya and Almajiri Schools should remain closed till further notice. UPDATE: Originally th epolicy for school closure was limited to 30 days but on 28th of March the governor of Kebbi state changed to an indefinite date. Also, religious schools have to close as well.

description:
Lagos state government closes all public and private schools from 23rd March.
After closing schools since march, Lagos state government on the 29th of July asks HER SS3 and TEC3 to resume on 3rd of Aug, in order to prepare for their West African Senior Secondary Certificate Exams. UPDATE: The Lagos State government has previously directed that all primary, secondary and tertiary institutions should be closed due to the pandemic on the 23rd of May. However, on the July 29th the commissioner of education announced that all the SS3 and Technical Studies (TEC3) students in both day and boarding schools in the state are to resume on Monday, August 3, 2020, to help them prepare for the forthcoming West Africa Senior Secondary Certificate Examination (WASSCE).
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description:
Lagos state government closes all public and private schools from 23rd March.
After closing schools since march, Lagos state government on the 29th of July asks HER SS3 and TEC3 to resume on 3rd of Aug, in order to prepare for their West African Senior Secondary Certificate Exams. UPDATE: The Lagos State government has previously directed that all primary, secondary and tertiary institutions should be closed due to the pandemic on the 23rd of May. However, on the July 29th the commissioner of education announced that all the SS3 and Technical Studies (TEC3) students in both day and boarding schools in the state are to resume on Monday, August 3, 2020, to help them prepare for the forthcoming West Africa Senior Secondary Certificate Examination (WASSCE).
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: In Ondo state, Nigeria, Secondary school students in exit classes resume on August 4 and to be participating in the 2020 WASSCE, according to the latest directive of the Federal Government.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with no conditions

description: Osun state, Nigeria reopens school on August 4 for exit students with following guidelines: Parents are expected to provide face masks/nose covers for their children or wards, while Principals and Proprietors of Schools are expected to ensure a tidy environment with desks arranged at least two meters apart. This social distancing  shall be ensured by Class Wardens. Also, The Ministry of Education shall provide buckets, soap, hand sanitizers, thermometer and also fumigate all schools. The Ministry of Health shall also provide Vitamin C tablets for students. NCDC or the Ministry of Health should be alerted in case of any sign of infection in any of the schools. Preschool, Primary schools and higher education institutions are still closed.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description: Environment unsafe to reopen schools (Imo State in Nigeria).  The government of Imo State has declared the environment as not yet conducive to reopen private and public schools.  This is owing to the coronavirus pandemic which, according to the government, has not been fully contained.   Prof. B.T.O Ikegwuoha stated that the federal Ministry of Education did not mandate all the 36 states to reopen their schools at the same time.  36 states can reopen their schools after September 17, 2020 based on the peculiarities of individual States.

description: On the 15th of October the state of Niger announced the reporting of schools supported by UNICEF. The reopening coincided with world's handwashing day. In Niger, children go to school in some of the most challenging contexts. In the midst of COVID-19, washing hands with soap remains one of the most effective barrier gestures against the pandemic. UNICEF ensured the provision of handwashing devices and soap and sensitization actions in primary schools across the country. In Niger, children go to school in some of the most challenging contexts. In the midst of COVID-19, washing hands with soap remains one of the most effective barrier gestures against the pandemic. UNICEF ensured the provision of handwashing devices and soap and sensitization actions in primary schools across the country. The aim is to ensure that every child in niger has an opportunity to good quality education without leaving behind the vulnerable children.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions

description: COVID-19 has reached state of emergency in Ondo, says Akeredolu, Ondo State Governor Oluwarotimi Akeredolu has expressed worries over the rising spike in COVID-19 cases in the state, with 100 new cases within eight days.  Akeredolu, who noted that as of Monday last week, the state had 74 cases, said that 174 confirmed cases had spread across the three senatorial districts of the state. While addressing journalists during the weekly briefing on the pandemic in Akure, the governor attributed the increase to non-committal attitude of the people to fight it. He said there were 1,052 reported cases, 1,257 samples collected, 71 active cases on admission, 18 deaths while 47 persons had been discharged so far.

description:
Nigeria will begin reopening its airports from July 8 following a three-month lull due to the coronavirus outbreak, the country's aviation minister said Wednesday. 

Flights will initially resume between the capital Abuja and Lagos. Airports in Kano, Port Harcourt, Owerri and Maiduguri will resume operations on July 11, and domestic flights at other airports will resume on July 15, Hadi Sirika said on Twitter.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: There is currently no curfew in Niger currently, there are also no restrictions regarding intercity travel. U.S citizens who travel to Niger are required to quarantine if they plan on staying for more than 14 days. All passengers are required to quarantine for at least seven days. Officials will visit each individual in quarantine to ensure they are following the regulations. Covid-19 testing takes place on passengers upon arrival before they quarantine. Public transportation is operating and also flights.

description:
ADVISORY TO NIGERIANS ON NOVEL CORONAVIRUS.

This is an updated advisory on the novel coronavirus 2019 (2019-nCoV), by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control. As this is a new virus, and new information is emerging every day, this advisory will be updated as new information and research on the virus and its impact on populations become available. The Nigerian Government is closely monitoring the ongoing novel coronavirus 2019 outbreak which originated in Wuhan, China.

description: Edo State government announce screening of travelers coming into the state from different entry points, especially the Benin Airport and motor parks on March 18.
On 19th March 2020 Anambra's governor announced all Hotels are directed to keep an accurate record of all their guests including names, phone numbers and addresses with immediate effect.

Nasarawa state, Nigeria, urges lawmakers on March 19, returning from foreign trips to go for COVID-19 test and isolate themselves for 14 days before appearing in the chambers for legislative activities.

Edo State asked all the residents to report persons who had just returned to the state in the last 30 days from Europe, Asia, America and other affected countries to the appropriate authorities, in order to provide screening and any required support to them.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 23, Cross River state government announced that all transport companies must keep a travel manifest for inbound and outbound passengers.
On March 23, Cross River state government announced that all Corporate and business organizations in the state must keep registers for visitors.

On March 23, Cross River state government announced that all corporate and business organizations must immediately report all guests and visitors that have a temperature above 38 degrees Celsius to the COVID-19 emergency center.
Imo State government announced commuters entering the state through the land borders are to be screened before being allowed entry from March 25.

On April 2, Edo State Government announced that hoteliers should take all safety precautions while dealing with clients. They are to obtain detailed travel history of their clients. For persons coming to self-isolate in their facility, they are to take necessary precautions and daily temperature checks, among other measures.

Kwara State Government on April 7 announced that it has traced no fewer than 75 people that had contact with the COVID-19 cases in the state as well as the suspected case at the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital (UITH).
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, The Kwara State Governor said 75 contacts of the infected patients had been traced and are being monitored by the COVID-19 Rapid Response Team of the medical advisory committee.

In an address monitored in Benin City, Governor Godwin Obaseki, said with 11 confirmed cases as at Wednesday, April 8, evidence showed that the number of cases was likely to increase significantly in the next few weeks. All government hospitals and Primary Healthcare Centres will be used as screening centres to screen citizens who believe they may have been exposed or suspect that they may have symptoms of Covid-19.  Now is completed the first set of training for all health workers in Edo State who will man the screening and isolation centres.
Nigeria - Abia Government on Friday, April 24th, said it had traced 209 contacts of the two index coronavirus cases in the state and placed them under surveillance in an isolation facility.

On April 28th, 2020 a high level technical and Rapid response surge team was deployed to Kano, Nigeria in order to intensify support of the coordination in intervention efforts. This includes the deployment of additional response commodities and supplies to Kano State.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The Edo State government has set up five additional screening centres across land borders with Ondo, Delta and Kogi states. The state Deputy Governor and Chairman of Covid-19 Response Technical Committee, Mr Philip Shaibu, disclosed on the 28th of April evening while briefing the press on activities of the committee. UPDATE: The Edo State government has set up five additional screening centres across land borders with Ondo, Delta and Kogi states.

On May 16th, 2020, Nigeria commenced Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) training specifically for younger male students, called Almajirai (also commonly spelled Almajiri), in Kano State. This training is for the purpose of reducing the risk of the spread of COVID-19 on the streets of the northern regions of Nigeria, and to move the boys to temporary medical centers before reuniting them with their families.

On June 1, Yahaya Bello, governor of Kogi said that contact tracing should be carried out house to house to identify those who might have made contact with the alleged Kogi COVID-19 index persons. The Kogi State incident management team should continue to thoroughly carry out the contact tracing. The contact tracing shall be fully covered by the mainstream media.

06 June 2020 | Abuja – 100 DAYS OF NIGERIA’S COVID-19 RESPONSE

On the 27th of February 2020, Nigeria confirmed its first case of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). One hundred days after, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) has reported 11,844 confirmed cases and 333 deaths. Additionally, 3,696 people have been treated and discharged successfully. The COVID-19 pandemic has affected over 100 countries across the world. Over 6 million people have been affected, and the number of deaths has exceeded 300,000 as at the 6th of June 2020.
type_sub_cat: A community’s epidemiological status
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: June 18, Nigeria - in Edo, the state government has appealed to residents to present or report themselves through the Edo State COVID-19 toll free response lines following any recent travel from high COVID-19 incident states within the country or contacts with persons with symptoms of the virus.

June 18, Nigeria - the state government has appealed to residents to present or report themselves through the Edo State COVID-19 toll free response lines following any recent travel from high COVID-19 incident states within the country or contacts with persons with symptoms of the virus
On July 2, Edo State Government says it has increased screening and testing capacity by setting up facilities in churches, mosques, and business establishments.

The Federal Road Safety Corps (FRSC), Brono State Command, and transport unions in the state on July 16 signed an agreement on enforcement of COVID-19 protocols on roads within the state.
They agreed that thermometers be provided for checking of temperature of all persons entering motor parks, just as the use of face masks by such persons would be enforced.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 2, The Edo State Government has cleared and exited 5,067 suspected Coronavirus (COVID-19) cases across the state’s 18 local government areas (LGAs), who have completed the compulsory 14-day follow up and tested negative. The Commissioner for Health, Dr. Patrick Okundia, who disclosed this to journalists in Benin City, said the cleared cases comprise 348 Persons of Interests (POI) and 4,719 others that had various degrees of contacts with confirmed cases.

description: Reports of a cluster of deaths from an undiagnosed disease were notified on 1 November 2020 through Event Based Surveillance in two states, Delta and Enugu, located in southern Nigeria. The Delta State health surveillance system had been informed of the outbreak on 30 October 2020, following a cluster of deaths presenting with similar symptoms.

description: On April 10, Kwara State Governor AbdulRahman AbdulRazaq has announced that they refurbished the state’s oxygen plant, over nine years after it last functioned at usable capacity. The revamped facility bolsters Kwara’s capabilities to manage Coronavirus (COVID-19) patients who may require ventilators for a lifeline. The Governor also commended the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) for helping the state to recover looted funds which have become useful in the campaign against COVID-19. AbdulRazaq said the recovered funds strengthened Kwara’s ability to put in place necessary facilities, among other counter-COVID-19 efforts. The Governor said the government has turned around the Sobi Specialist Hospital which is now the COVID-19 response center of the state. The administration is now working on having an isolation centre in Offa after which another would be created in General Hospital Kaiama. They had bought five new ambulances (three on the ground and two are on the way) and a mobile x-ray machine. They have also 10 ventilators now and they expect to have 30 by the end of the month.
type_sub_cat: Ventilators
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Task Force in Gombe, Nigeria has procured over 200 Million Naira worth of medical supplies and consumables including personal protective equipment (PPEs), which have been prepositioned in all health care facilities across the state

description: The Task Force in Gombe, Nigeria has procured over 200 Million Naira worth of medical supplies and consumables including personal protective equipment (PPEs), which have been prepositioned in all health care facilities across the state

description: The Covid-19 task center have created three centres for isolating Covid-19 patients as follows: a) A 150-bed capacity hospital at Kwadon which has been fully renovated and furnished for the management of mild-to-moderate cases; b) A 12-bed capacity Intensive Care Unit (ICU) at the State Specialist Hospital, Gombe has been established and is fully equipped for the management of severe cases including mechanical ventilation and other intensive care needs; c) A 50-bed capacity fully equipped facility at Federal Teaching Hospital, Gombe; d) Additional isolation facilities are also being prepared at Funakaye and Kaltungo LGAs in order to ensure effective coverage of the state.
type_sub_cat: Temporary Quarantine Centers

description: On April 17, the Kogi state government in Nigeria has set up temporary isolation wards at the Confluence Advanced Medical Diagnostic and Imaging Centre (CAMDIC)
type_sub_cat: Temporary Quarantine Centers

description: On April 17, the Ebonyi state government had quipped isolation/treatment centres in Unity Square Abakaliki and another at Ishielu."We have also selected six general hospitals to serve as observation centres, two in each senatorial zone in our response protocol."

description: April 17 - Imo State government said it has equipped six isolation centres at the Okigwe General Hospital, Aboh Mbaise General Hospital, Orlu General Hospital, Federal Medical Centre, Umuguma General Hospital and the Ultra-modern Well-Being Centre.

description: Following evolving evidence on the transmission of COVID-19, the World Health Organization (WHO) provided recommendations for the wearing of face masks by the general public. This is especially important where there is ongoing widespread transmission and physical distancing is difficult, such as in public transport, markets, and confined or crowded environments. In Nigeria, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 mandated the use of face masks or coverings in public spaces, on the 27th of April 2020. The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) published advisories on the use of face masks and guidance on making cloth masks.
type_sub_cat: Masks
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On April 29, The Edo State Government has received 350,000 facemasks, 10,000 pairs of medical gloves, 18,000 pieces of testing kits, 200 cartons of disinfectant, 40 pieces of decontamination equipment, all valued at over N120 million, from the management of Yongxing Steel Company. The governor expressed appreciation to the Chinese Consulate-General and Yongxing Steel Company for the donation.
type_sub_cat: Masks

description: On May 7, Kogi State Governor Yahaya Bello has announced full insurance for health workers involved in the fight against coronavirus spread in the state. He said in Lokoja when officials of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control led by Dr Noah Andrew visited him. The moves were aimed at boosting health workers’ confidence. NCDC delegation that the state Ministry of Health had deployed health workers in the 239 wards making up the state, as well as two officials who would sensitize residents to the dangers of the virus in each of the wards. They have set up three modern isolation/containment centres in the state with 130 bed spaces. Also provided emergency and toll-free numbers for the general public to call in and report suspected cases of Covid-19.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Materials
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
OWERRI NORTH COVID 19 SENSITIZATION TEAM ARRIVES NAZE WARD

Naze communities of Owerri North local government received the COVID 19 sensitization team on the 8th of May, 2020, led by the chairman, Owerri North local government Interim Management Committee, Engineer Lams Ibe.

Engineer Lams Ibe announced the purpose of the sensitization program, he said, "the sensitization program is aimed at promoting a heightened awareness of the deadly pandemic in all the communities of Owerri North local government".
type_sub_cat: Masks
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Osun state, Nigeria, on May 20 commissioned an isolation center with 160 beds in Osogbo as part of efforts to curb the coronavirus pandemic in the state. The government also announced that they had renovated and equipped three other isolation centres which include, 130-bed facility in Ejigbo; 12-bed capacity in Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, a 20-bed isolation centre and 8-bed Intensive Care Unit at State Specialist Hospital, Asubiaro, Osogbo, making 342-isolation beds and eight ICU-bed facility in the state.
type_sub_cat: Temporary Quarantine Centers

This is intended to reduce the amount of necessary contract-tracing should the person ultimately test positive.

description:
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) continues to lead the public health response to the COVID-19 outbreak in Nigeria. Following the review of recent restriction measures by the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19, NCDC has developed new guidelines for places of worship in Nigeria. This is to ensure safe gatherings and prevent exposures to COVID-19 infection in religious settings.

On the 2nd of June 2020, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 announced the relaxation of the previous ban placed on religious settings, allowing faith groups to meet while adhering to public health and social measures.
type_sub_cat: Masks
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

On the 2nd of June 2020, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 announced the relaxation of the previous ban placed on religious settings, allowing faith groups to meet while adhering to public health and social measures.

description: On July 4, The Kwara State government has announced the receipt of N243m as financial donations from private individuals and corporate bodies between March 27th and July 4th. These expenses covered the purchase of military grade Toyota Land Cruiser Ambulances; automated ventilators and several other Intensive Care Unit (ICU) gadgets/equipment; production of hand sanitizers; and the cost of running the activities of the technical committee and its subcommittees, the statement reads. The expenses also covered the cost of the palliatives that were distributed during the lockdown; renovation of the Sobi Specialist Hospital and the Hajj Camp; mass production of face masks, purchase of surgical masks, digital thermometers, N95 and respirator-sperien 5311 and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Others are; medical supplies and consumables; security expenses; training; allowances for medical personnel and other supportive staff in charge of the pandemic; part-renovation of the Offa General Hospital as an isolation centre; and patients’ management, among others.
type_sub_cat: Masks

description: On Friday, July 24th, the Nigerian Government conducted training for 50 TB/HIV/ COVID-19 coordinators on basic Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) practices in Kano State. IPC practices include ensuring early triage, recognition, and source control at the point of entry to a facility, the implementation of hygienic precautions for all patients within facilities, the proper use and disposal of all PPE, and proper social distancing of patients as well as proper ventilation for all facilities housing known COVID-19 patients. Specific precautions vary depending on the type of facility (e.g. patient room, laboratory, waiting/holding room, etc.)

description:
25 September 2020 | Abuja – NCDC Donates Treatment Centre to Federal Capital Territory for Management of Cases

On the 25th of September 2020, the Honourable Minister of Health, Dr Osagie Ehanire led the official handover ceremony of the Infectious Disease Care Centre built and equipped by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), to the management of the University of Abuja Teaching Hospital (UATH), Gwagwalada. This project was born out of the need for a treatment centre for serious infectious diseases in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) following the 2018 Lassa fever outbreak.

description:
UN support three Abuja area councils with $1.1m for COVID-19 palliatives, am
Party chairs killed in Nasarawa, Katsina
2 hours ago
How delayed preventive plans encouraged yellow fever, others, by FG, experts
1 hour ago
Oil, gas firms move for better environment via reduced methane emissions
2 hours ago

To cushion the effect of COVID-19 on residents of the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) has flagged off the distribution of palliatives and cash transfer to three Abuja Area Councils with the sum of $1.1million. The area councils are Abuja Municipal (AMAC), Bwari and Gwagwalada. 

The palliative include the donation of N14, 000 and 75,000kg of grains from the Federal Strategic Grain Reserve to 15,000 households in the FCT. To ease transfer of the fund, account was opened for beneficiaries in a commercial bank.

description: On 19th March 2020 Anambra's governor announced that management of all hotels should take a reading of the temperature of guests and visitors with non-contact infra-red thermometers. Temperatures over 37.9 degrees Celsius should be reported to the PHEOC. Management of all hotels and restaurants must check the temperature of all their staff and customers daily. Staff with temperatures more than 37.9 degrees Celsius should not be allowed to serve and must report to the hospital.

description: On 19th March 2020 Anambra's governor announced  all night clubs, lounges and bars are directed to provide infra-red thermometers with immediate effect.

Ebonyi state governor, Nigeria, directed the Ministry of Health and State Committee on Anti Coronary Virus to deploy all health officers to all market, rice mills, banks and other public event management centres to carry out test on people randomly from march 20.
Ebonyi state, Nigiera, stated that the health workers are immediately directed by March 21 to move from house to house to use 150 infrared thermometer devices to test all Ebonyians.
On March 23, Cross River state government announced that all corporate and business organizations must take temperature checks of guests and visitors using a non-contact infra-red thermometer.
In Nigeria, the Abia State Government has announced  plans to establish three coronavirus  testing centres.
On April 11, 2020 Nigeria set up two new laboratories for testing COVID-19 cases, including Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital in Kano, Nigeria, bringing the total number of labs to 11.

In Nigeria on April 17, Ebonyi Commissioner for Health, Umezuruike Daniel, said the state had been working hard to ensure the virus does not get there.He expressed pride in the Virology Centre of the Alex Ekwueme Federal Teaching Hospital in Ebonyi State, which has been receiving samples from neighbouring states for COVID-19 testing.

The Ministerial team of FMoH left en route to Lokoja on May 7 to work with the Kogi State government. It includes officials of NCDC and Dept. of Hospital Services of the Ministry of Health. They will ensure that the state has adequate testing capacity and shall also advocate for the engagement of traditional rulers and community leaders in surveillance efforts of the State.
The Bauchi State Government is carrying out mass testing of residents during the 10-day lockdown in Bauchi state from Tuesday, May 12 2020, to Friday, May 22 2020.

description: The government of Zamfara State in Nigeria has launced zero-contact testing booths for carrying out coronavirus tests in the State.

On May 21, The Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) team leader, Okoli Innocent gave the commendation when he led other members of the Center to Kwara to inspect laboratories in preparation for establishing of Molecular Testing Centre in the state to test for the virus. Reacting to the visit of the Dr Okoli Innocent led team, Kwara State Deputy Governor and Chairman Technical Committee on COVID-19, Mr Kayode Alabi who was represented by Commissioner for Health, Dr Raji Razaq, appreciated the NCDC for the move to set of Molecular Testing Center in the state.

description: In Nigeria, Gov. Okezie  Ikpeazu of Abia on June 2 announced that the state government would commence massive testing for COVID-19 as part of efforts to curb its  spread.

"The Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) of the Task Force (in Oyo, Nigeria) will on Wednesday commence the community testing for COVID-19, with the aim of determining the behaviour of the virus in the state.
The statement indicated that the exercise, which is scheduled to hold in 10 locations, will kick off in three different sites in Ibadan on Wednesday."

Ebonyi state, Nigeria, advices all EXCO members and government officials, especially those of the ministries of finance and that of budget,  to undergo COVID-19 tests within June 4 and June 10 while all the government offices in the state is closed.

20 June 2020 | Abuja – Clarification of COVID-19 Testing Expansion in Nigeria in light of Comments by Officials of Cross River State

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is aware of recent statements regarding the country’s COVID-19 testing processes, by the Commissioners of Information and Health in Cross River State.

Given our mandate to protect the health of all Nigerians, we are obliged to state the facts

description: In Nigeria, on the 24th of June, all lawmakers in the north central Kaduna state house of assembly were ordered to undergo COVID-19 test. The order also covers all other staff after a positive case was recorded among the assembly staff last week. The order was given by Kaduna Assembly Speaker, Yusuf Zailani.
At least 13 Nigerian lawmakers have tested positive for coronavirus, local media reported Wednesday. Health authority asks infected MPs to go into self-isolation  | 24.06.2020

description: On July 6, Edo State Government said no fewer than 201 health workers have tested positive for coronavirus disease (COVID-19) since the outbreak of the pandemic in the state. They said that a total of 201 health workers have tested positive to the virus since the outbreak of the pandemic in the state. The government will not relent in ensuring the welfare of the state’s health workforce as well as continue to intensify efforts to contain the pandemic across communities in the state and protect Edo people. Meanwhile, Edo House of Assembly has adjourned plenary indefinitely following the result of a second confirmed case of the pandemic in the complex. Speaker of the House, Frank Okiye, said the adjournment was to enable lawmakers and workers of the assembly to undergo COVID-19 test.

21 September 2020 | Abuja – NCDC and NIMR launch COVID-19 Household Seroprevalence Surveys in Selected States of Nigeria

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) and Nigeria Institute for Medical Research (NIMR) and their partners are conducting household surveys in four states in Nigeria to better understand the burden of COVID-19 infection in Nigeria. These seroprevalence surveys, which will be carried out in Gombe, Enugu, Nasarawa and Lagos States will provide the best evidence yet, on the extent of COVID-19 infection in Nigeria.

description: The Federal Government on Friday inaugurated the first Infectious Disease Centre (IDC), in the Federal Capital Territory, The centre would improve Nigeria’s capacity to respond to all infectious diseases.  "With laboratory testing and case management in one location, there is a much shorter time between sample collection and infection confirmation."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Nigerian scientists announce development of cheaper, faster COVID-19 test kits

COVID-19: Ogun begins second round of community testing.  he Ogun State Government said it has commenced its community-based coronavirus testing across the 20 local government areas of the state in order to increase the test rate in the state and its environs.
The Commissioner for Health, Tomi Coker, made this known in a statement, explaining that the decision to domesticate Covid-19 testing in all the council areas of the state was on the national recommendation of community-based testing as a means of ascertaining the prevalence, improving early case detection and treatment of both symptomatic and asymptomatic cases.

The Federal Government on Friday inaugurated the first Infectious Disease Centre (IDC), in the Federal Capital Territory, The centre would improve Nigeria’s capacity to respond to all infectious diseases.  "With laboratory testing and case management in one location, there is a much shorter time between sample collection and infection confirmation." UPDATE: The Nigerian Minister of Health has indicated their COVID testing has increased to 3500 /per day due to the risks associated with institutions reopening

description:
The Lagos State Government has confirmed some positive COVID-19 cases in a secondary boarding school on the mainland.

This was disclosed in a press release issued on Friday, November 6, 2020, by the Lagos State Commissioner for Health, Prof. Akin Abayomi.

Abayomi in his statement said that a member of the school’s staff was confirmed positive for COVID-19 infection on November 2, 2020, and contact tracing revealed that a student and four contacts of the affected staff also tested positive to COVID-19

description:
November 6, 2020. An outbreak of an unidentified disease has claimed the lives of at least 57 people in the southeastern Nigerian state of Enugu, according to local media.
Nigeria/Alvaro1984 18

The communities of Ette and Umuopu have been affected since September.

Vincent Oshomi, a Disease Surveillance and Notification officer in the region, said before vomiting blood, the victims showed symptoms of diarrhea and convulsion.

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) says epidemiologists have been deployed. Initial samples from sick people returned negative for COVID-19, Lassa and yellow fever.

description: Nigeria's Centre for Disease Control from September 2020 suggests that travellers should self-isolate. They should avoid situations where they would be mixed with other people or family members for a period of 14 days. Those who are self-isolating include all returning travelers to Nigeria, Anyone who has been in close contact with a confirmed case of Covid-19, Discharged Covid-19 patients for at least one week. Effective from the 5th of september, the Presidential task force has revised the quarantine protocol for all returning travelers to Nigeria. Non-Nigerians may be refused entry at a cost to the airlines, Nigerians may be given access with a mandatory 14 day quarantine under governmental facilities for supervision. On arrival to Nigeria Passengers shall go through screening, passengers will proceed on a 7 day self-isolation. Persons found negative after the 7 day self-isolation will be allowed to exit self-isolation, the international travel from Nigeria to other countries is country specific.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

Nigeria President Muhammadu Buhari announced: “Based on the advice of the Federal Ministry of Health and the NCDC, I am directing the cessation of all movements in Lagos and the FCT for an initial period of 14 days with effect from 11pm on Monday, 30th March 2020. This restriction will also apply to Ogun State due to its close proximity to Lagos and the high traffic between the two States.”. the lockdown in Ogun state was supposed to start from March 30, was shifted to commence from April 3, after the state government made a request to the federal government to allow them to provide food for their residents. UPDATE: the original lockdown was set to start from March 30, 2020, it has been postponed to April 3.

Plateau state, Nigeria, orders 7 day lockdown from 12 midnight, April 9 to 11pm of April 15. During this period, there will be no movement of any kind except for staff on essential duty.These include security agencies, medical and health workers, power and energy staff, fire service, media, telecom operators and fuel tankers.

On April 10, Kwara State Government has announced total lockdown of the state. The new measure banned all vehicular movement, including private vehicles, all manners of shops and markets. Food sellers and operators of medicine stores are allowed to operate on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays between 10a.m. and 2p.m. All health workers remain exempted from this lockdown. Kwara Farmers who can identify themselves with any registered farming associations are allowed to go to their farms during the total lockdown the government has declared to prevent the spread of Corona Virus in the state. The Kwara State Technical Committee on COVID-19 also exempted journalists on duty from the lockdown in line with global best practices during such emergencies.  It is also to be noted that previous waivers to manufacturing firms are still valid on the condition that they maintain social distancing and scale down their operations. Petrol stations, banks, and hospitals are also exempted from the lockdown on the condition that all safety protocols are adhered to.

The Anambra State Government of Nigeria announced on April 11, 2020 the implementation of a complete lockdown that would last the next two weeks. Only those delivering essential services would be permitted to move around the state and all borders with neighboring states would be closed.

The Katsina State Government brought into force on Saturday April 11, 2020 the "Persons Movement (Restriction) Order 2020." The lockdown order restricts movement of people in the local government areas under lockdown. The local governments under lockdown are those in which cases of Coronavirus (Covid-19) have been recorded.

The Anambra State Government of Nigeria announced on April 11, 2020 the implementation of a complete lockdown that would last the next two weeks. Only those delivering essential services would be permitted to move around the state and all borders with neighboring states would be closed. On April 25, this lockdown was lifted; while boundaries between other states remain closed, food markets, restaurants, and bars have been allowed to reopen if maintaining social distancing. Movement within the state was also reopened.
Nigeria Federal government has extended the lockdown in Ogun state for another 14 days after the first phase. The extended lockdown started form 11:59 pm on Monday, 13th of April, 2020.

he Ogun State Governor, Prince Dapo Abiodun on Friday July 3 extended weekend lockdown in the state by another two weeks.

description: The Anambra State Government of Nigeria announced on May 25, 2020 the creation of community COVID-19 teams for each of the state's wards, following the success of the COVID-19 task force at a state level. These smaller teams would be comprised of the Officer-in-Charge of Primary Healthcare Center, the Community Woman Leader, the Community Youth Leader, the Representative of the Ministry of Health and the Representative of the Civil Society. The teams would be headed by the Councilor of the Ward, but the Local Government Chairman and his Medical Team shall supervise the activities of the entire Team. This new structure is intended to help ramp up testing in local communities.

description: Nigeria's Anambra State Government announced on June 2, 2020 new protocol for the sampling and reporting of COVID-19 cases. According to the announcement, all members of the Nigerian Medical Association practicing in Anambra State were hereby expected to inform the Ministry of Health once they collect samples of suspected Covid-19 patients for testing. This is in order to ameliorate a prior issue of members collecting samples and sending them to the testing centers on their own. All Covid-19 efforts in Anambra State with regards to the collection of samples and the presentation of specimen to NCDC must be centralized going forward.

description:
On the 14th of December 2020, the Nigerian State called Anambra's ministry of health has allocated Tablets for 21 LGA LMCUs. The tablets are to be used to capture data that will be sent into the Nigeria Health Information System data base; data entry for logistics, supply chain monitoring and supportive supervision on an App called Survey CTO.Ezenyimulu noted that the LGA LMCU Coordinators would be expected to enter the state’s data at the grassroots.

“Before now they have issues with reporting devices, but today we are grateful to the FG for providing these tools for the LMCUs to capture data.

“We are hopeful of achieving 100 per cent reporting rate now that LMCUs have been enabled, because the tablets are coming with data for them to do their job effectively,” she added.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers

description: On April 28, The Edo State Governor, Godwin Obaseki has launched an online homeschooling platform, EDO-BEST@Home, which enables pupils learn from resources downloaded from an online database while at home. Obaseki said the platform is part of steps taken by the state government to ensure academic engagement by students, who ought to have resumed for a new term on April 27, but would have to remain at home as a result of the partial lockdown imposed to check the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The platform supported by State Universal Basic Education Board (SUBEB), MTN Nigeria also benefiting from a strong alliance between the government, the private sector, and the World Bank. The state is also developing interactive quizzes delivered to parents’ mobile phones to maximize the interaction between learners and teachers.

description: on June 27th, 2020, The Rivers State Executive Council has approved Guidelines for Marraiges/Weddings in the state during the period of Covid 19.
type_text: The Rivers State Executive Council has approved Guidelines for Marraiges/Weddings in the state during the period of Covid 19.  Prospective Couples would need to get an approval/ apply to the Governor through the Commisioner for Social Welfare.  All Weddings/Marraiges have an attendance limit of 50 people.  The names, addresses and phone number of all attendees made available with the application (To enable quick contact tracing if the need arises).  Soap and running water has to be kept at the entrance to the venue in not less than three places while all attendees are to wear face masks and maintain social distancing of not less than 2 meters.  Church weddings are to be conducted between 9am and 12noon, while traditional weddings are to be conducted between 4pm and 7pm.  A representative of the Ministry would be present to observe the event.  A fine of N10,000,000 is to be paid by anyone that puts people at risk by breaking this regulation.

description: Lagos, Nigeria, 29 September 2020 – The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), in partnership with the Lagos State Government and the Federal Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs, Disaster Management and Social Development (FMHDS) has launched an Unconditional Cash Transfer project targeting the poor and vulnerable in Lagos state, largely funded by the European Union (EU). description:
The Lagos State tax authority issued guidance providing additional tax relief measures in response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. 

Previously, the Lagos State tax authority issued guidance (in March 2020 and again in June 2020) providing certain tax relief measures. The additional relief measures now include:

    Installment payments for resolving the tax liabilities of certain taxpayers
    Waiver of late-payment penalties for “pay-as-you-earn” (PAYE) liabilities for March through May 2020
    Waiver of late-filing penalties for 2020 annual tax returns (Form A)
type_sub_cat: Gathering information related to COVID-19 from the public

description: On July 29, Kogi State government has announced that they set to partner with the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, NCDC, in the governor’s effort to stem the increasing rate of infection, and also curb the menace of the coronavirus pandemic in the state. It will be more collaboration and synergy between the state and the agency to fastrack the mitigation and logical solution to the pandemic.

description:
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) joins the global movement to motivate all citizens to wear a face mask. World Mask Week (WMW) aims to reinforce the importance of wearing a face mask to reduce the spread of COVID-19. In the absence of a vaccine that can prevent infection, and as COVID-19 cases increase globally, citizens must depend on non-pharmaceutical measures, which include the use of face masks, hand washing, physical distancing and supportive management of confirmed cases to mitigate the impact of the disease.

World Mask Week, an initiative from a coalition of organisations including the Pandemic Action Network (PAN), World Health Organisation (WHO), Africa CDC and private companies working to mitigate the effects of COVID-19 globally, will run from August 7th -14th 2020.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: MSF has mobilised a team of 140 community health workers who go from house to house and visit health facilities and other places where people gather to raise awareness of the disease and how to protect against it. "We also broadcast messages on the radio to reach a lot of people," says health promoter Ali. "There are many rumours and lots of misinformation accompanying this pandemic, so we are working actively with the community to share the right informations about the disease and to ensure that everyone is part of the response."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
20th September 2020 | Abuja - PUBLIC HEALTH ADVISORY- NO EVIDENCE ON BENEFIT OF ‘AIR DOCTOR’ TAGS AGAINST COVID-19

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is aware of the wrong use of body worn labels or tags often marketed as ‘Air Doctor’ by members of the public. There is no scientific evidence that these tags can protect individuals from getting infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

NCDC’s advice is that anyone that chooses to wear these tags, should continue to adhere to the other non-pharmaceutical interventions, which we know reduces the risk of transmission of the virus.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The CDC in Nigeria revised health Guidance and now beliefs virus is airborne, the CDC revealed that COVID-19 can spread through virus lingering in the air, sometimes for hours, thereby reversing its earlier pronouncement and acknowledging concerns widely voiced by public health experts about the airborne transmission of the virus.

description:
LAGOS, Oct 16 (Reuters) - A total of 181 students and staff at a private boarding school in the Nigerian capital Lagos have tested positive for coronavirus, state health authorities said on Friday.

Authorities said there had been a “minor but significant” outbreak among the 441 staff and students at the school in the suburb of Lekki and said most of the now-quarantined positive cases were asymptomatic.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
07 November 2020 | Abuja – Response to Suspected Yellow Fever Outbreak in Delta and Enugu States

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is currently supporting the Delta and Enugu State Governments, in response to suspected outbreak of yellow fever. This is following reports of a sudden spike in cases and deaths in some communities in both states.

On the 2nd and 3rd of November 2020, NCDC was notified by the State Ministries of Health of Delta and Enugu States respectively, of cases presenting with symptoms indicative of a viral haemorrhagic fever. Most cases presented with fever, headache, fatigue, jaundice vomiting (with or without blood) among others.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Dec. 13, 2020 (MOI) Ndi Anambra have been urged to maintain hygiene and safety so as to be healthy this Yuletide season.

President, Kamac Foundation, a Non Governmental Organisation (NGO), Mr Chike Amos Ekwughe said this while being interviewed by an Information Officer at Nibo, Awka South Local Government Area (LGA), Anambra State.

Mr Ekwughe, a Civil Engineer said that indigenes and residents of the state should not throw caution to the winds in terms of hygiene and safety, especially at this period of celebration.

He added that sons and daughters of Anambra, who would return for Christmas and New Year celebrations should do this to promote their well being.

The president enjoined Ndi Anambra to comply with Gov. Willie Obiano’s call to maintain COVID-19 protocols.

The protocols include regular hand washing under running water with soup, wearing of nose masks and keeping social distancing in crowded areas.

Ekwughe said that compliance with the pandemic protocols was necessary and should be part of daily interaction to promote healthy living.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 24, Kwara State Government announced the cancellation of Eid-ul-adha congregational prayers across the state, citing the steep rise in the state’s Covid-19 cases and the danger of such a large gathering worsening the situation. The Government also announced a ban on vigils in churches and mosques while restating the ban on concert, clubbing, beer parlour, and bar in hotels. Kayode Alabi, Deputy Governor and Chairman of the Kwara State Technical Committee on COVID-19, told a news briefing in Ilorin, the capital city, that the decision to cancel the Eid prayers was a painful but necessary one to save lives.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Nigeria's Centre for Disease Control released a statement on the 30th of November 2020, introducing stricter measures for travel bans. This included cross-country and cross-city travel. It is an awareness campaign aimed at reducing the number of infections in the upcoming Christmas and New Year festives. Non-essential travel locally and internationally have been discouraged. Travel from countries that have recorded a higher rate of infections to Nigeria have also been discouraged. Local travels from urban or semi-urban areas to rural areas has been discouraged as rural areas have weak infrastructure to deal with any viral surges. Upon arrival to Nigeria travellers are encouraged to quarantine for seven days. Social gatherings are to be virtually conducted and the holidays are to involve only closer family members. A social distancing of 2 meters is recommended. Sanitizers and washing hands is also recommended.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Nigeria is enforcing a cross-country and cross-city travel ban for the christmas and new year festives. Travellers from countries that recorded a higher rate of infections to Nigeria are not encouraged. Passengers are tested through a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in their country of exit 120 hours before boarding. Furthermore, upon arrival in Nigeria, travellers should self-quarantine for seven days. Non-essential local and international travels are discouraged. Social and religious gatherings are only allowed through video calls. Family gatherings should ensure sanitization, 2 meter social distancing, washing of hands, avoid people showing symptoms. People above the age of 60 should avoid having visitors and friends coming over. Urban and semi-urban travel to rural areas is discouraged due to the weak infrastructure from such areas.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

However, the government allows for two religious services to take place on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday accordingly and that all these services should not extend beyond 2.00 pm on such days.

description: The Ekiti State Government is banning all public gatherings of more than 20 people, anywhere in the state from Monday, January 11, 2021, at 6:00 am until further notice. However, the government allows for two religious services to take place on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday accordingly and that all these services should not extend beyond 2.00 pm on such days. UPDATE: The Ekiti State Government from Monday, January 11, 2021, banned all public gatherings or more than 20 people until further notice but allowed for two religious services which cannot extend beyond 2 pm to take place on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. On Sunday, January 17, 2021, it was announced that the restriction of a maximum of 20 persons in confined spaces is removed to allow half the capacity of venues for all events indoors and social distance of two-meter spacing for outdoor activities. Restrictions earlier placed on the number of religious services are also lifted.

description: On 19th March Anambra State government announced that handshaking, hugging and all other forms of physical contact are strongly discouraged. A distance of 6-feet should be maintained between customers and traders.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On 19th March 2020 Anambra's governor announced that all night clubs, lounges and bars are directed to adhere strictly to the basic standards of social distancing with immediately effective.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On March 23, Governor Yahaya Bello of Kogi State has given directives that tricycle (Keke) operators may carry only one (1) passenger at a time and must provide hand sanitizers for use by their passengers. Also, regular 4-wheeled taxis may carry only three (3) passengers at a time (1 in front and 2 behind) and must provide hand sanitizers for use by their passengers. Furthermore, buses may carry only two (2) passengers per row of seats, subject to a maximum of 10 passengers per trip for any type of bus. Relevant officials are empowered to stop and enforce compliance. Any defaulters will be arrested.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation

description: On April 2, Edo State Government, as part of a strategy to enforce social distancing in the transportation system, suspended the daily collection of revenues for the month of April. Maintenance of social distancing of at least one metre are to be strictly adhered to. The seating arrangements are that cars must carry one passenger in front and two at the back; for buses, one passenger in front and two in each row.

description: Ebonyi State Governor, on April 4, directed that anybody seen outside his/her house must wear a face mask, adding that handkerchief, head tie, and pre-made medical mask could serve the purpose of face mask.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description:
On April 1, Cross River state government stated that no citizen or resident of the state would be allowed to leave their home without a face mask starting Friday, April 3.

UPDATE: On April 2, Cross River state government stated that no citizen or resident of the state would be allowed to leave their home without a face mask beginning on Monday, April 6. UPDATE: The original 'no mask no movement' lockdown was set to begin on April 3, it has now been postponed and set to begin on April 5.

description: Nasarawa state, Nigeria, makes it mandatory to wear face mask from May 6.

description: On May 28, 2020 Nigeria's Anambra State Government signed the new COVID-19 Bill into law. Under this new Covid-19 Law it is an offense to be seen in the public without a face mask. The offense attracts a fine of ten thousand naira or some hours of community service.

description: The state government of Ekiti in Nigeria required the use of face masks in public beginning April 14 and strengthened the enforcement mechanism on June 30.. description: Residents of Kwara State must use face mask in public places, keep physical distancing or stay indoors beginning from Friday July 24th, the government announced on July 20, with the State Technical Committee's protective applications on COVID-19, nobody would be allowed into any public building, markets, malls, transport, banks, and so on without their proper use of the face masks as a safety measure to lessen the transmission of the virus.

description: By July 31st, 2020, the government would commence strict enforcement of the Kwara State Infectious Diseases Regulations 2020. Thenceforth, anyone seen outside without proper use of the face mask will be arrested, prosecuted in a mobile court, and taken to any of our quarantine centres. Their samples will then be taken and they will be held until their status is known. We want to emphasise that shop owners or business managers, drivers of commercial or private vehicles who allow persons without face masks into their shops or vehicles would be arrested alongside offending passengers and be taken to quarantine centres, have their samples taken and be held until their result is out.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
